collection1.title: Escaped prisoner apprehended in D.C. after hours-long manhunt
collection1.text: The prisoner was suspected of robbing 12 banks and getting away on a bicycle, but his escape from Inova Fairfax Hospital on Tuesday morning would prove even more improbable.
collection1.video-caption: Fairfax Police Chief Col. Edwin C. Roessler Jr. told members of the media Tuesday that escaped prisoner Wossen Assaye, 42, had been apprehended. U.S. Marshal for the Eastern District of Virginia Robert Mathieson described how Assaye managed to overpower a female contract security officer and escape. (WUSA9)
collection1.gallery-caption: Wossen Assaye allegedly overpowered a guard and carjacked two vehicles to make his escape. He was captured in the District.

collection1.title: Obama administration, citing climate risks, plans steep cuts in greenhouse-gas pollution

text.text: The Obama administration on Tuesday outlined an ambitious plan for slashing U.S. greenhouse-gas pollution over the next decade, calling for accelerating the shift from fossil fuels to clean energy to stave off the worst effects of climate change.

caption.text: Silhouetted against the sky at dusk, emissions spew from the smokestacks at Westar Energy’s Jeffrey Energy Center coal-fired power plant near St. Mary’s, Kan. (Charlie Riedel/AP)

collection1.title: Iran nuclear talks continue past self-imposed midnight deadline

text.text: LAUSANNE, SWITZERLAND — Negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program blew past a Tuesday deadline, U.S. officials said, with diplomats struggling to reach con­sensus on the difficult issues of sanctions, enrichment research and future limits.

collection1.video-caption: A senior Iranian nuclear negotiator said “unresolved issues” persist as countries continue negotiating for a nuclear deal. (Reuters)

collection1.title: Photos: The battle in Tikrit as the Islamic State loses control

text.text: Iraqi soldiers and Shiite militia took back the center of the Iraqi city of Tikrit on Tuesday from Islamic State militants. It figures to be a major victory against the Islamists, although there are indications that fighting may continue.

collection1.caption: Iraqi security forces and Shiite paramilitary fighters hold an Islamic State flag, which they pulled down in Tikrit on Tuesday. Iraqi troops aided by Shi’ite paramilitaries and Sunni tribal fighters have reached the center of Tikrit after securing the Sunni city’s southern and western sections from the militants, Prime Minister Haidar al-Abadi said. (Alaa al-Marjani/Reuters)

collection1.title: How Trevor Noah can save his tenure at ‘The Daily Show’ before it starts

text.text: Just a day after Trevor Noah was welcomed by some as an exciting new choice to host “The Daily Show,” the South African comedian, who is little-known in the United States, has come in for criticism as writers and fans have begun to pore over his body of work. The biggest target has been the archives of Noah’s Twitter feed, where he tried out material that targeted Jewish women, heavier women, Jews and Israel.

collection1.caption: Trevor Noah in 2009. (Bongiwe Mchunu/The Star via Associated Press)

collection1.title: Indiana and the defining divisions in American politics

text.text: The controversy over Indiana’s religious-freedom law highlights the most fundamental divisions that now define American politics. For all the recent talk that foreign policy or income inequality will dominate the 2016 campaign, the firestorm over Indiana is a reminder of the underlying power of values and social issues to shape political identity.

collection1.video-caption: Indiana Gov. Mike Pence (R) says his state will "correct" the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, saying the law "does not give anyone a license deny services to gay and lesbian couples." (Reuters)

collection1.title: Nigeria opposition candidate wins presidency in historic race

text.text: KADUNA, Nigeria — In a historic moment for Africa’s most ­populous country, former dictator Muhammadu Buhari won Nigeria’s presidency on Tuesday, the first time in 16 years of democracy that an opposition candidate has defeated a sitting president.

collection1.gallery-caption: Former military dictator Muhammadu Buhari said it was time “to heal wounds,” a day after the president conceded electoral defeat.

collection1.title: Obama administration ends long hold on military aid to Egypt

text.text: The United States will resume suspended military aid to Egypt, the White House said Tuesday, signaling the Obama administration’s eagerness to help a key Middle Eastern ally confront militant threats despite concerns about its repressive stance on human rights.

collection1.video-caption: A U.S.-made F-16 fighter flown by the Egyptian air force during a 2007 mission. (Staff Sgt. Amy Abbott/U.S. Air Force via AFP/Getty Images)

collection1.title: Lufthansa knew of co-pilot’s previous ‘severe depression’ in 2009

text.text: BERLIN — The co-pilot who crashed Flight 9525 into a French mountainside last week had informed the German carrier Lufthansa in 2009 about a “previous episode of severe depression,” the airline said on Tuesday, raising fresh questions about the series of decisions that allowed Andreas Lubitz to stay in the skies.

collection1.video-caption: A Lufthansa aircraft flies past the headquarters of Germanwings during takeoff from Cologne-Bonn airport on March 27. (Wolfgang Rattay/Reuters)

collection1.title: President Obama commutes sentences of 22 drug offenders

text.text: President Obama on Tuesday commuted the sentences of 22 drug offenders, the largest batch of prisoners to be granted early release under his administration as it steps up an overhaul of the nation’s criminal justice system.

collection1.video-caption: President Obama and first lady Michelle Obama depart the White House on Monday. (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

collection1.title: Indiana law draws Republican White House hopefuls into the culture wars

text.text: The national debate over an Indiana religious-liberties law seen as anti-gay has drawn the entire field of Republican presidential contenders into the divisive culture wars, which badly damaged Mitt Romney in 2012 and which GOP leaders eagerly sought to avoid in the 2016 race.

collection1.video-caption: Indiana Gov. Mike Pence (R) says his state will "correct" the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, saying the law "does not give anyone a license deny services to gay and lesbian couples." (Reuters)

collection1.title: Turkish prosecutor dies after being held hostage in a courthouse, reports say
collection1.caption: Members of a Turkish police special forces unit prepare to enter the Justice Palace in Istanbul on March 31. (Osman Orsal/Reuters)

collection1.title: Disciples of Christ will hold its convention in Indianapolis despite religious freedom law

text.text: Organizers of a mainline Protestant church gathering say they will not move their 2017 convention from Indianapolis due to a hotly contested new Religious Freedom Restoration Act as initially planned.

collection1.caption: Sharon Watkins is general minister and president of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). Photo used with permission, http://disciples.org

collection1.title: Andrew Getty, 47, dead in latest Getty family tragedy

text.text: This post has been updated.

collection1.caption: Gordon Getty with his son Andrew Getty in 1976. (AP)

collection1.title: Singer-songwriter Joni Mitchell hospitalized after being found unconscious

text.text: This post has been updated.

collection1.caption: Musician Joni Mitchell performs at the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz International Trumpet Competition and Herbie Hancock Tribute in Hollywood October 28, 2007. (Max Morse/Reuters)

collection1.title: Indiana law draws Republican White House hopefuls into the culture wars

text.text: The national debate over an Indiana religious-liberties law seen as anti-gay has drawn the entire field of Republican presidential contenders into the divisive culture wars, which badly damaged Mitt Romney in 2012 and which GOP leaders eagerly sought to avoid in the 2016 race.

collection1.video-caption: Indiana Gov. Mike Pence (R) says his state will "correct" the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, saying the law "does not give anyone a license deny services to gay and lesbian couples." (Reuters)

collection1.title: Pet Rock inventor Gary Dahl dies at 78. He put a rock in a box and sold millions.

text.text: Before toy stores were stocked with pet plants, virtual pets and pillow pets, an advertising copywriter called Gary Ross Dahl was dreaming up the Pet Rock, a 1970s novelty toy craze since called a “ridiculously successful marketing scheme.”

collection1.caption: Gary Ross Dahl, the creator of the popular 1970s fad the Pet Rock, has died at age 78 in Oregon. Dahl’s wife, Marguerite Dahl, confirmed that her husband of 40 years died March 23 of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. (Marguerite Dahl via AP)

collection1.title: Nigeria’s new president, an ex-military man, vows to crush Boko Haram

text.text: ABUJA, Nigeria — When the next president of Nigeria, Muhammadu Buhari, is asked how he will defeat Boko Haram militants who have terrorized this country, he is quick to remind people of his previous career.

collection1.caption: Nigerian president-elect Buhari, right, will need to reform the military, says Darren Kew, a professor at the University of Massachusetts at Boston. (-/Agence France-Presse via Getty Images)
collection1.video-caption: Nigeria’s president-elect Buhari vows to target Boko Haram. (Reuters)
collection1.gallery-caption: Former military dictator Muhammadu Buhari said it was time “to heal wounds,” a day after the president conceded electoral defeat.

collection1.title: Uber driver arrested after breaking into a passenger’s home, police say

text.text: An UberX driver circled back to the home of a passenger he’d recently dropped off at the airport and tried to burglarize the place — only to find that his intended victim had a roommate, Denver police said.

collection1.caption: Gerald Montgomery. (Denver Police Department via Reuters)

collection1.title: U.S. establishes sanctions program to combat cyberattacks, cyberspying

text.text: President Obama on Wednesday signed an executive order establishing the first sanctions program to allow the administration to impose penalties on individuals overseas who engage in destructive attacks or commercial espionage in cyberspace.

collection1.video-caption: A man types on a computer keyboard in Warsaw in this February 28, 2013 illustration file picture. (KACPER PEMPEL/REUTERS)

collection1.title: Noose is found hanging from tree on Duke’s campus

text.text: This post has been updated.

collection1.caption: Hundreds of students gathered at Duke Wednesday after a noose was found on campus. (Photo obtained by the Post.)

collection1.title: Arkansas governor vetoes new Arkansas right of publicity bill

text.text: Gov. Asa Hutchinson’s veto message strikes me as quite right:

collection1.title: Can a Muslim president defeat Boko Haram? Nigerians are betting on it
collection1.text: A northern Nigeria Muslim leader who promised to pursue a nonreligious agenda as president will now have to deal with an Islamic terrorist insurgency that has wreaked chaos in the country’s north.
collection1.video-caption: Celebrations broke out in Muhammadu Buhari’s home town after the opposition leader won the presidential election by more than 2 million votes, according to a Reuters tally. (Reuters)

collection1.title: Rebel forces push farther into key Yemeni port city of Aden

text.text: SANAA, Yemen — Shiite rebel forces backed by tanks and heavy machine guns pushed deeper into Yemen’s second-largest city on Wednesday in a bid to strengthen their hold even as Saudi-led airstrikes attempt to cut off their supply lines and cripple their capabilities.

collection1.caption: Saudi airstrikes in Yemen
collection1.gallery-caption: The campaign, with a coalition of Arab nations, is an effort to dislodge Houthi rebels sweeping through Yemen.

collection1.title: In Tikrit, a celebratory mood but lingering concerns

text.text: TIKRIT, Iraq — After a month of battle, the sporadic rattle of gunfire heard in downtown Tikrit on Wednesday was largely celebratory, hailing the Iraqi government’s most significant victory yet over Islamic State militants.

collection1.caption: Iraqi security forces celebrate in Tikrit on April 1, 2015, a day after the prime minister declared victory in the weeks-long battle to retake the city from the Islamic State group. (Ahmad Al-Rubaye/AFP/Getty Images)
collection1.gallery-caption: Mass graves containing the bodies of soldiers killed by the militant group have been found in parts of the city.

collection1.title: Calif. governor orders statewide mandatory water restrictions

text.text: As California endures its fourth year of a crippling drought, Gov. Jerry Brown announced Wednesday the state’s first mandatory water restrictions, ordering cities and towns to cut water use by 25 percent.

collection1.gallery-caption: Climate models suggest many Western states will be facing longer and harsher droughts in the decades to come.

collection1.title: Jerry Brown battles Calif. water crisis created by his father, Gov. Pat Brown

text.text: In 1979, a balding man with a touch of gray at the temples and glasses like windshields was holding forth on his favorite subject: H2O. Pat Brown, former governor of California — and father of current California governor Jerry Brown (D) — was asking: What’s the value of water?

collection1.caption: Former California governor Edmund G. “Pat” Brown and his wife, Bernice, after their son, Gov. Edmund G. “Jerry” Brown Jr., was inaugurated to his second term in Sacramento in 1979. (Walter Zaboski/AP)

collection1.title: Sen. Bob Menendez: Humble beginnings to a 5-star, $1,000 per night Paris hotel suite

text.text: Back when Sen. Bob Menendez was just a chubby Cuban American kid in a tenement apartment in Union City, New Jersey, his mother instilled in him one, all-important lesson: “failure is not an option.” With that mantra in mind, Menendez embarked on a remarkable rise from poverty to power that culminated in the chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Capitol Hill.

collection1.caption: The Park Hyatt Paris Vendôme (Courtesy of Hyatt Hotels)

collection1.title: Rebels advance to the center of Aden, Yemen’s second-largest city

text.text: SANAA, YEMEN — Shiite rebel forces and their allies pushed into the heart of Yemen’s second-largest city and seized the presidential palace Thursday, scoring another major advance and exposing the apparent limitations of Saudi-led airstrikes seeking to restore the country’s president.

collection1.caption: Shiite rebels known as Houthis hold up their weapons to protest against Saudi-led airstrikes, during a rally in Sanaa, Yemen, Wednesday, April 1, 2015. (AP Photo/Hani Mohammed) (Hani Mohammed/AP)
collection1.gallery-caption: The campaign, with a coalition of Arab nations, is an effort to dislodge Houthi rebels sweeping through Yemen.

collection1.title: Menendez indictment marks first big corruption case involving a super PAC

text.text: The federal bribery case against Democratic Sen. Robert Menendez of New Jersey marks the first time large-scale super PAC donations have figured prominently as evidence of a political corruption scheme, renewing questions about how truly independently such groups operate.

collection1.video-caption: Sen. Robert Menendez (D-N.J.) says he is confident he will be “vindicated.” (Reuters)

collection1.title: Poll: Bush now tops GOP field; Clinton runs ahead of all Republicans

text.text: Former Florida governor Jeb Bush now leads the field of prospective Republican candidates for the party’s 2016 presidential nomination, but former secretary of state Hillary Rodham Clinton enjoys a decided advantage over Bush and other potential GOP rivals in hypothetical general election matchups, according to a new Washington Post-ABC News poll.

collection1.caption: Poll: Clinton's star is fading, but GOP has catching up to do
collection1.video-caption: Hillary Clinton leads all potential opponents in a new Washington Post/ABC News poll. (Nicholas Kamm/AFP/Getty Images)

collection1.title: Hillary Clinton’s favorable rating drops below 50 percent. And yet she still leads big.

text.text: Hillary Clinton is still leading all comers in early polls of the 2016 presidential race. But these days, that has much more to do with the Republicans' weaknesses than with her strengths.

collection1.caption: Hillary Clinton listens before delivering remarks at an event in New York on Nov. 21, 2014. (AP Photo/Bebeto Matthews, File)

collection1.title: Suicide bomber kills 18 and wounds scores in eastern Afghanistan

text.text: KABUL — A suicide bomber blew himself up in a crowd of protesters in the eastern Afghanistan province of Khost on Thursday, killing 18 and wounding scores more, Afghan government officials said.

collection1.caption: Afghan firefighters try to extinguish fire at the site of a suicide bomb blast in the Khost province on Thursday. (Ahmadullah Ahmadi/European Pressphoto Agency)
collection1.video-caption: A suicide bomber kills more than a dozen people during a demonstration against corruption in the eastern province of Khost. (Reuters)

collection1.title: Rahm Emanuel votes, jokes media is his ‘family’

text.text: CHICAGO -- Mayor Rahm Emanuel went to the polls Thursday morning to cast his ballot during early voting in his runoff election.

collection1.caption: Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel casts his ballot early in the mayoral runoff election on Thursday in Chicago. (By Sean Sullivan/The Washington Post)

collection1.title: 10 quotations from the late Rev. Robert H. Schuller that could inspire anyone
Co-pilot in Germanwings crash said to have researched online about suicide

text.text: BERLIN — The co-pilot thought to have deliberately crashed Germanwings Flight 9525 had been trawling the Internet for ways to commit suicide and information about the safety mechanisms on cockpit doors, German prosecutors said Thursday.

collection1.video-caption: German prosecutors said the co-pilot, who is believed to have deliberately crashed a passenger jet, had searched the Internet for ways to commit suicide before the crash. (Reuters)
collection1.gallery-caption: As the plane’s remains are sorted, questions linger.

collection1.title: Duke student admitted hanging noose from tree on campus, school officials say

text.text: A student has admitted hanging a noose from a tree on campus, Duke University officials said Thursday afternoon.

collection1.caption: This photo provided by Henry Washington shows a rope noose hung from a tree Wednesday, April 1, 2015, in Durham, N.C. Duke University officials are trying to determine who hung the noose, what the president of the elite Southern school described as a vicious symbol in a region where lynchings were once used to terrorize black residents. (AP Photo/Henry Washington)

collection1.title: Al-Shabab attacks Kenyan university, killing at least 147

text.text: NAIROBI — Masked al-Shabab militants stormed dormitories at a university in eastern Kenya early Thursday, killing at least 147 people in the worst terror attack on Kenyan soil in nearly two decades, officials said.

collection1.gallery-caption: A Nairobi stadium is now a crisis center for victims and survivors of the al-Shabab slaughter of 147 people at Garissa University.

collection1.title: Shipwrecked sailor says he survived 66 days at sea with a lot of prayers

text.text: Updated with additional details from the “Today” show.

collection1.title: Shipwrecked sailor says he survived 66 days at sea with a lot of prayers

text.text: Updated with additional details from the “Today” show.

collection1.title: Iran agrees to nuclear restrictions in framework deal with world powers

text.text: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iran agreed in principle to accept significant restrictions on its nuclear facilities for at least a decade and submit to international inspections under a framework deal announced Thursday after months of contentious negotiations with the United States and other world powers.

collection1.caption: Highlights of the Iran deal
collection1.video-caption: President Obama announced that negotiators from Iran, the United State and other world powers agreed to a framework for a final agreement to curb Tehran’s nuclear program. (AP)

collection1.title: Kenya faces the grim aftermath of school massacre

text.text: GARISSA, Kenya — Survivors of a bloody college campus assault in this eastern city prepared to spend a second night in tents at a makeshift camp on the city’s airstrip waiting to be bused home, as rescuers removed bodies of students from dormitories on Friday and airlifted injured survivors to the capital city of Nairobi.

collection1.gallery-caption: A Nairobi stadium is now a crisis center for victims and survivors of the al-Shabab slaughter of 147 people at Garissa University.

collection1.title: China’s former security chief charged with corruption, leaking state secrets

text.text: BEIJING — China charged former security chief Zhou Yongkang on Friday with taking bribes, abusing his power and disclosing state secrets, paving the way for one of the most significant political trials in the country in decades and underlining President Xi Jinping’s dramatic consolidation of power.

collection1.video-caption: Chinese government prosecutors announced Friday that Zhou Yongkang, right, has been formally charged with corruption and leaking of state secrets, setting the stage for him to become the highest-level politician to stand trial in China in more than three decades. (Ng Han Guan/AP)

collection1.title: Lubitz used autopilot to accelerate plane into mountain, black box shows

text.text: BERLIN — The co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525 used the onboard autopilot to put the plane into a descent and repeatedly increase the speed of the Airbus A320 as it headed straight for a mountainside, according to an initial assessment of data recovered from the aircraft’s second black box.

collection1.caption: Germanwings incident
collection1.video-caption: German prosecutors said the co-pilot, who is believed to have deliberately crashed a passenger jet, had searched the Internet for ways to commit suicide before the crash. (Reuters)
collection1.gallery-caption: As the plane’s remains are sorted, questions linger.

collection1.title: With outlines of a deal, Iran embarks on uncharted territory with the U.S.

text.text: It started with a simple handshake. On Sept. 26, 2013, the top diplomats of the United States and Iran — bitter foes for nearly 35 years — exchanged awkward greetings on the sidelines of a U.N. conference in New York.

collection1.caption: Highlights of the Iran deal
collection1.video-caption: Iranians celebrated on the streets of Tehran following the announcement that a framework agreement has been reached on Iran's nuclear program between the country and the major world powers. (The Washington Post)
collection1.gallery-caption: In the streets of Tehran, many wonder if the preliminary nuclear accord could mean an end to sanctions.

collection1.title: Christian activists: Indiana law tried to shield companies against gay marriage

text.text: Amid the backlash over the controversial religious-liberties law in Indiana, Gov. Mike Pence and other state officials insisted the measure was never intended to permit business owners to deny service to gays and lesbians.

collection1.video-caption: Indiana Gov. Mike Pence (R) says his state will “correct” the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, saying the law "does not give anyone a license to deny services to gay and lesbian couples.” (Reuters)

collection1.title: Alabama inmate free after three decades on death row. How the case against him unraveled.

text.text: Anthony Ray Hinton was one of Alabama’s longest-serving death row inmates, having spent more than half his life incarcerated. Now, after three decades of insisting that he was innocent in the 1985 murders of two men, the 58-year-old Hinton is finally a free man.

collection1.caption: Anthony Ray Hinton wipes tears following his release. (Bob Farley/EPA)

collection1.title: Iran nuclear pact stirs hope — and fear — of new political order in Mideast

text.text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Iranian President Hassan Rouhani pledged Friday that his country would honor what he called a historic agreement to curb its nuclear program, provided that world powers uphold their end of the deal to ease economic pressures.

collection1.caption: Highlights of the Iran deal
collection1.video-caption: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani said negotiations that produced a framework nuclear accord are the first step toward better ties between Iran and the world. (Reuters)
collection1.gallery-caption: In the streets of Tehran, many wonder if the preliminary nuclear accord could mean an end to sanctions.

collection1.title: Everything you need to know about the ‘blood moon’ apocalypse debate

text.text: For a very brief time on Saturday, the moon will turn an orangey-red, depending on conditions, during an Easter weekend lunar eclipse. Although the east coast of the United States will be shut out of this particular “blood moon” in the sky, it’s just the third of four such eclipses spanning a period of a couple years — an event known as a tetrad.

collection1.caption: The moon glows a red hue during a total lunar eclipse Tuesday, April 15, 2014, as seen from the Milwaukee area. That eclipse was the first of four total lunar eclipses to take place between 2014 to 2015. (AP Photo/Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel, Mike De Sisti)

collection1.title: Easter Monday egg-citement has been a White House tradition since 1878
collection1.text: Every year, the president of the United States invites children and their families to roll eggs in the back yard of the White House on Easter Monday. That might sound like an unusual tradition for the president’s home, but it has taken place there since 1878.
collection1.caption: Warren Sonnemann took home the prize basket for winning the Easter Egg Roll in 1923. (Library of Congress)
collection1.video-caption: Children dance around a maypole at the White House Easter Egg Roll, circa 1930. (Library of Congress)

collection1.title: Bob Corker, the ex-Chattanooga mayor at center of debate on Iran nuclear pact
collection1.text: Even Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) acknowledges that he is an unlikely leader of the debate over the superpower framework for curtailing Iran’s nuclear program.
collection1.video-caption: U.S. Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, finds himself the central figure in Capitol Hill’s intense debate over the nuclear framework with Iran. (Jonathan Ernst/Reuters)

collection1.title: Sarah Brady, gun control activist, dies at 73
Final Four provides chance to debate NBA’s No. 1 pick
collection1.text: The Final Four is usually a time to celebrate the best teams in college basketball, not extend the debate over the amateur game’s best player. That has changed some this year with NBA executives and scouts in agreement that either Duke freshman center Jahlil Okafor or Kentucky freshman big man Karl-Anthony Towns will be the No. 1 pick come June.
collection1.caption: The general consensus is Duke’s Jahlil Okafor, above, or Kentucky’s Karl-Anthony Towns will go No. 1 in the NBA draft. (Grant Halverson/Getty Images)

collection1.title: Militant group threatens additional attacks on Kenya

text.text: GARISSA, Kenya — Two days after al-Shabab militants slaughtered 148 people in a devastating attack on a university in northeastern Kenya, the Islamic extremists issued a chilling threat that its terrorizing of Kenya was far from over.

collection1.video-caption: Crowds gather at a Garissa mortuary to see the bodies of the al-Shabab gunmen behind the deadly Kenya university attack, as families search for loved ones who went missing after the bloody assault. (Reuters)
collection1.gallery-caption: A Nairobi stadium is now a crisis center for victims and survivors of the al-Shabab slaughter of 147 people at Garissa University.

collection1.title: Al-Shabab statement on deadly campus assault in Kenya
collection1.text: The following English-language statement, released by the SITE intelligence group, was posted Saturday on al-Shabab-affiliated Web sites and jihadist Twitter accounts.
collection1.video-caption: Kenyan Muslims demonstrate against Thursday's attack by al-Shabab gunmen on a college campus in Garissa, Kenya. The sign proclaims solidarity with non-Muslims who were targeted. (Ben Curtis/AP)

collection1.title: Obama, Clinton, Kerry and how Iran shapes legacies and political futures

text.text: It is perhaps only an accident of history that three of the key actors in the diplomatic efforts to deny Iran a nuclear bomb are the 2004, 2008, 2012 and probable 2016 Democratic presidential nominees. But their intertwined ambitions provide a dramatic backdrop to the unfolding and unfinished story.

collection1.video-caption: President Obama returns to the Oval Office from the Rose Garden on Thursday after announcing a breakthrough in nuclear talks with Iran. (Pablo Martinez Monsivais/AP)
collection1.gallery-caption: In the streets of Tehran, many wonder if the preliminary nuclear accord could mean an end to sanctions.

collection1.title: Total lunar eclipse dazzles skywatchers
How to get Californians to use less water — without forcing them to

text.text: The water situation in California is getting downright scary. Last week, the Department of Water Resources found “no snow whatsoever” in its Sierra Nevada snowpack survey and Gov. Jerry Brown declared mandatory reductions in water usage in the state. In particular, the more than 400 agencies supplying water to urban areas will have to cut total usage by 25 percent below 2013 levels.

collection1.caption: A sprinkler waters a lawn at San Francisco’s Golden Gate Park on Wednesday. As California enters its fourth year of severe drought and the state’s snowpack is at record lows, Gov. Jerry Brown has ordered a statewide 25 percent mandatory water usage reduction for residents, businesses and farms. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

collection1.title: 2015 Final Four: Jahlil Okafor, Karl-Anthony Towns, Frank Kaminsky make this a big deal

text.text: INDIANAPOLIS — A Final Four of futuristic athletic talent doubles as a kind of throwback. As a Saturday evening brims with Duke playing Michigan State and Kentucky playing Wisconsin, the floor of Lucas Oil Stadium will teem with what Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski called “a great collection of big men.”

collection1.caption: John Calipari on Karl-Anthony Towns’s emergence: “It’s ridiculous how far Karl has come in one year.” (Andy Lyons/Getty Images)
collection1.video-caption: The NCAA tournament is down to the Final Four, as Wisconsin takes on Kentucky and Michigan State faces Duke. The Post's Mike Hume, Adam Kilgore and Gene Wang look at the matchups and offer their predictions. (Tom LeGro/The Washington Post)

collection1.title: As water runs dry, Californians brace for a new way of life

text.text: PASADENA, Calif. — His lawn was thick, healthy and gorgeous, and Mike Duran was in love. “It was so green. It was so lush,” he said. But the relationship had financial issues. Watering the grass cost about $1,200 every other month in this drought-stricken state.

collection1.caption: Carlos Salguero of the Onelawn landscaping company installs a section of fake grass at a home in Burlingame, Calif. Artificial lawns have emerged as a water-saving alternative for many Californians. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)
collection1.gallery-caption: Climate models suggest many Western states will be facing longer and harsher droughts in the decades to come.

collection1.title: John Feinstein: Duke shows the necessary improvement

text.text: INDIANAPOLIS — With 3 minutes 35 seconds left in Saturday night’s first Final Four semifinal, Duke center Jahlil Okafor went to the foul line with the Blue Devils leading Michigan State by a comfortable 13-point margin. Okafor was 2 for 5 from the free throw line at that point — his Achilles’ heel throughout an otherwise superb freshman season.

collection1.gallery-caption: Duke routs Michigan State in opening game while Wisconsin ruin’s Kentucky’s perfect season in the second semifinal.
